1120038852482281472.text: What are your favorite dumb moments?

1120038850796060674.text: Grabbing your phone to look something up. Get distracted by a notification. Put the phone down. Remember you wanted to look something up. Repeat process... three or four times.

1120038849202262016.text: Grabbing toothpaste to brush your teeth then remembering you also need to put cream in your hair, then putting the toothpaste in your hair.

1120038847587528704.text: Tried to pee standing up without pooping. Had to poop anyway. No choice but to turn around and sit down. But couldn’t stop the pee. Chaos as I tried to take off pants and turn and sit. (I was 12)

1120038845934964741.text: Chewing on a large piece of meet and swallowed one part but it was connected to the other part with a tendon. Almost died as I had to hold my breath and quickly chew the second part to swallow the whole.

1120038844156514315.text: Champagne glass in left hand, bottle in right. Leaned against the bar and it was slippery so I fell over and there the glass of champagne in my face and poured the bottle in my ear. Ended up on the floor blind and deaf.

1068527708257177601.text: Mail is kinda annoying in that mail isn’t checked in the background. Or it is but only when your in the folder. So I have a folder named notifications which I have to go to to have it refreshed. On the laptop I would just see the count on the folder go up.

1068525203414630400.text: Oh yeah; Handoff never really worked predictably from iPhone to MacBook Pro. Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn’t. It seemed slow, and I just couldn’t depend on it. But between iPhone and iPad: it always works! It is fast and natural and almost like it is the same device.

1068520829237919745.text: I only have two screen filled with apps. Here they are:pic.twitter.com/qyBtIvTYDk

1068520474605346816.text: Conclusion: the iPad Pro can be a professional tool, but I’m aware of some limitations. I like the focus it gives me, and the flexibility. Walking around with an iPad feels ‘light’. Any questions?

1068520472264957952.text: I also use Google’s docs a lot. And Keynote and pages, also @evernote, Facebook, Linkedin and Twitter, and @feedly. Trello also works, and I have some finance apps too.

1068520468422909953.text: I also understand the ipad is not for everyone. If you’re a designer or developer you want your big screen and mouse and whatever you need to do your work. Fine. My life revolves around Slack, Mail, Calendar, Notes, Reminders and my browser. So this is perfect for me.

1068520464199245826.text: Difficult to measure, but: I feel more focused and less distracted on the iPad. My focus is on two apps at a time, at the most. And I’m less likely to also have a browser with 20 tabs demanding my attention or a messy desktop.

1068520459614924806.text: I spent some time really learning the multi gestures, and how to use split screen. I enjoy having my mail on the left, and iCal on the right and scheduling meetings as I copy stuff from mail. Then with a four finger pinch I go home to quickly launch a different app. Like magic.

1068520455668097024.text: They keyboard is indispensable. Typing on the screen is awkward. I want the iPad on my lap as I mostly work from a beanbag, couch, hammock or at a standing table. The new Folio keyboard is great, unless it is dark because there’s no backlight.

1068520448751616008.text: That’s a limitation of @SlackHQ as you can only copy one message at a time, and this person had looked up the urls and pasted them as separate messages. That was the first time in 3 weeks I missed my laptop.

1068520446721576961.text: Someone sent me 10 links in @SlackHQ. I wanted them in a doc so decided to copy paste them. On a desktop that would be; drag cursor over text, copy selected text, paste in doc. On iPad that means; press first link, wait for pop-up, copy the one link, go to doc, paste x 10 times

1068520444511174656.text: iOS is stable, until you try to do a lot at the same time. I have a full calendar and when I’m moving meetings around or editing them I often manage to crash the Calendar app. I just restart it and it is fine, but I do feel like a power user if I manage to crash apps.

1068520442464370688.text: Font handling is chaotic. I’ve used the iPad Pro do make keynote presentations and I’d like to use the fonts we use at @thenextweb but you’ll need a separate app for that and I haven’t looked into it further.

1020245057591562240.text: If the iPad is going to replace my laptop I need to be able to copy and paste and handle text with relative ease.

1020245055922233344.text: Now I'm not saying the iPad sucks, because I love it and it is my favorite piece  of technology. Seriously. But I do think text-editing needs work in iOS. It just feels like it hasn't been seriously looked at since the introduction of the first iPhone.

1020245054449963008.text: Conclusion: when it comes to simple text-editing, which is 90% of most people's work, you're better off using a 34 year old Macintosh than a 2018 iPad.

1020245052851990528.text: ...wait for pop-up to appear, select 'Copy'. Move to place where text needs to go, repeat all steps above, but with 'paste'

1020245051383910400.text: iPad: press finger on sentence to copy. Wait for cursor and pop-up to appear, select 'select' from pop-up, word is selected, drag blue dot across sentence (this often fails, especially when you need to go to the beginning of sentence, or the sentence spans multiple paragraphs)...

1020245049890701312.text: Macintosh: move mouse to beginning of text, click and drag (intuitive & effortless), with other hand press command + c, move mouse to other place and click, use other hand for command + v. Done.

1020245048183619584.text: The original Macintosh (128k memory, 8 Mhz chip) could compute your typed text 2000 times faster than you could type it. 90% of my work is text based. Now try to copy and paste a piece of text on an iPad and compare that to doing the same thing on a Macintosh:
